awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How do publication and funding filters shape the science that we do, and how we learn from it?
awd_abstract_narration:
Science provides an extraordinarily powerful tool for investigating nature, and nature supplies an
endless abundance of research topics that are ripe for scientists to investigate. Faced with such
abundance, scientists must regularly choose where to place their efforts: which questions to pursue and
which to leave for another day, which results to prepare for publication and which to set aside, and so
on. When making these decisions, researchers face incentives that scientific funders and scientific
journals create through the peer‐review processes that funders and journals use to ensure quality and
rigor in the science they support and publish. Yet we understand very little about how the incentives
created by peer‐review in scientific funding and publication shape the scientific activity of individual
investigators, and how those decisions scale up to impact the aggregate knowledge that science creates.
In this project, we will develop new mathematical theory to understand how incentives created by
scientific funders and journals affect individual scientific activity and the subsequent production of
scientific knowledge. This theory will provide a foundation for evaluating proposed refinements of
funding or publication practices, and for understanding whether these changes will nudge the scientific
enterprise towards a more reliable and expansive understanding of the natural world.

We will focus on two questions. First, how do journals' publication decisions shape the ability of their
readership to learn from the scientific literature? Second, how do the incentives created by funding and
publication structures motivate scientists to work on certain projects and shy away from others? For
each question, we will ask how peer‐review filters function differently for basic versus applied research.
We will investigate these questions by building and analyzing mathematical models that incorporate
elements of information theory, economics, forecasting assessment, and statistics. In the long run, this
work will deepen our understanding of science as a social process by revealing how scientific institutions
generate incentives that shape the direction of scientific inquiry. More immediately, it will provide a
theoretical framework to explore how possible changes to the peer‐review process such as registered
reports or pre‐print servers may change scientists' collective process of learning and discovery. Finally,
we will develop an online module to help readers become savvier consumers of the scientific literature,
and we will share our findings with the editorial board of a leading biological journal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Science is a human endeavor. Broadly, our work helps to understand how the norms and institutions of science influence the decisions that scientists make when developing their research programs. Those decisions in turn shape the knowledge that scientists produce. By unpacking the incentives that scientific norms and institutions create, we build a more robust and expansive understanding of why scientific knowledge is largely reliable. Our work also identifies how potential nudges to the scientific process might shift scientific activity, and generates predictions about how those shifts will affect scientific productivity.

In this project, we have specifically examined how several integral components of contemporary science impact researchers’ willingness to take on scientific risks. In science, the safest research programs—in the sense that they are most likely to yield publishable results—are probably not the most productive ones. Several lines of evidence suggest that many of the most important breakthroughs arise when scientists take risks, pursuing lines of research that have a high likelihood of failing entirely, but that will pay rich dividends should they succeed. Researchers and funders alike are concerned that too many impediments stand in the way of high-risk, high-reward science.

One such impediment is a consequence of the peer review system that is so central to scientific activity. Many projects are reviewed at multiple stages: before the work is done (ex ante) to determine if the study is worth funding, and after the work is done (ex post) to determine if the results are worth publishing. Using mathematical models of the scientific process, we find that ex ante peer review discourages risky research because reviewers tend to expect that risky studies are unlikely to be successful, whereas with ex post review the outcome of the research is already known. The tension between projects that are most likely to survive ex ante review versus those that are most likely to survive ex post review is a major dynamic that shapes contemporary scientific activity. Our theory thus suggests why grant proposals inevitably seem more risk averse than results presented in top-tier journals, and sounds a note of caution about how ex ante peer review of journal publications might shift scientific activity. Separately, this work also suggests why convening grant reviewers as a panel is especially important for supporting research that has the potential to resolve scientific controversies.

Another impediment involves the way that scientists are rewarded for their labor. Because it is difficult for employers to monitor the effort that researchers put into their projects, scientists are rewarded for their results, as a way of indirectly incentivizing effort. We have developed mathematical models to look at the consequences of this fact on scientists’ willingness to take professional risks. Scientists can be risk-averse in some ways — few are willing to risk losing their research funding or even their job should a high-risk, high-reward line of investigation fail to pan out. When rewarded in part or entirely based on results, researchers will choose safer projects than would be optimal to maximize the rate of scientific discovery. This work reveals an additional reason why funding programs designed to foster risky research often fail to attract proposals for high-risk, high-return science
